EFFL: Egalitarian Fairness in Federated Learning for Mitigating Matthew Effect

Jiashi Gao, Changwu Huang, Ming Tang, Xin Yao, Xuetao Wei
Department of Computer Science and Engineering
Southern University of Science and Technology
Shenzhen 518055, P.R. China
12131101@mail.sustech.edu.cn,
{huangcw3,tangm3,xiny,weixt}@sustech.edu.cn
&Shin Hwei Tan
Department of Computer Science and Software Engineering
Concordia University
Montreal, Canada
shinhwei.tan@concordia.ca Corresponding Author.
Abstract

Recent advances in federated learning (FL) enable collaborative training of machine learning (ML) models from large-scale and widely dispersed clients while protecting their privacy. However, when different clients’ datasets are heterogeneous, traditional FL mechanisms produce a global model that does not adequately represent the poorer clients with limited data resources, resulting in lower accuracy and higher bias on their local data. According to the Matthew effect, which describes how the advantaged gain more advantage and the disadvantaged lose more over time, deploying such a global model in client applications may worsen the resource disparity among the clients and harm the principles of social welfare and fairness. To mitigate the Matthew effect, we propose Egalitarian Fairness Federated Learning (EFFL), where egalitarian fairness refers to the global model learned from FL has: ❶ equal accuracy among clients; ❷ equal decision bias among clients. Besides achieving egalitarian fairness among the clients, EFFL also aims for performance optimality, minimizing the empirical risk loss and the bias for each client; both are essential for any ML model training, whether centralized or decentralized. We formulate EFFL as a constrained multi-constrained multi-objectives optimization (MCMOO) problem, with the decision bias and egalitarian fairness as constraints and the minimization of the empirical risk losses on all clients as multiple objectives to be optimized. We propose a gradient-based three-stage algorithm to obtain the Pareto optimal solutions within the constraint space. Extensive experiments demonstrate that EFFL outperforms other state-of-the-art FL algorithms in achieving a high-performance global model with enhanced egalitarian fairness among all clients.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) (McMahan et al., 2017) has emerged as a significant learning paradigm in which clients utilize their local data to train a global model collaboratively without sharing data. FL has attracted wide attention from various fields, especially in domains where data privacy and security are critical, such as healthcare, finance, and social networks. However, when the data distribution among clients is heterogeneous, the global model may perform inconsistently across different clients. This raises a client-level fairness issue: how to define and achieve a fair model performance for each client. From the perspective of commercial or profit-driven clients, contribution fairness (Tay et al., 2022; Liu et al., 2022) is attractive, which requires that the model performance on each client is proportional to their data resource contribution to the FL model.

In the real-world, clients may have unequal data resources due to historical or unavoidable factors. They deserve fair treatment based on social welfare and equality principles. However, contribution fairness worsens the resource plight of poorer clients, creating the Matthew effect (Merton, 1968). As shown in Fig. 1 (a), a lower-performance model may impair the data generation capabilities of poorer clients, exacerbating the disparity with richer clients over time and undermining social welfare and equality.

To mitigate the Matthew effect, we define egalitarian fairness in FL settings, which requires that the global model exhibits equal performance across clients. We consider two aspects of equal performance: ❶ Accuracy: accuracy reflects how well the global model fits the local data of clients; thus equal accuracy performance can enhance the poor-clients decision quality; ❷ Decision bias: decision bias reflects how fair of the global model decision on different protected groups such as gender, race, or religion within the client, thus equal decision bias performance can enhance the poor-clients reputation and decision credibility.

Attaining egalitarian fairness in FL settings presents significant challenges. ❶ First, egalitarian fairness requires equal performance across all clients, which creates a trade-off with the general objective of maximizing performance during model training. This is a crucial issue as participants may not want to compromise the overall performance for the sake of equality. This trade-off is particularly pronounced when dealing with heterogeneous clients, where the global model displays varied performance; ❷ The second challenge is that heterogeneous local datasets can lead to conflicting gradient descent directions, posing the trade-off that improving the performance for one client could potentially degrade the performance of others; ❸ Furthermore, as we consider egalitarian fairness in decision bias, it is noted that there is a potential trade-off between accuracy and decision bias (Wang et al., 2021).

Several works have focused on client-level fair model training in FL. Mohri et al. (2019) proposed a min-max-based approach that prioritized the model training optimization towards the worst-performing client. However, they failed to achieve performance equality, especially when there were more than two clients. Cui et al. (2021) simultaneously minimized the empirical risk loss across all clients. Li et al. (2021) allowed clients to fine-tune the global model on local data. These methods enhance the model’s representation of all clients but cannot guarantee to narrow the gap between the better-performing and the worse-performing clients. To achieve equal model performance, improving the model fitting towards the data distribution of the poorer clients is necessary. Li et al. (2019) proposed q-FFL, which enhances the weights of the poorer clients in the aggregation process to achieve equal accuracy across the clients. However, the method is heuristic and depends on a hyperparameter q𝑞q , which is difficult to be tuned to achieve the optimal result.

Our main contributions include: ❶ We propose an FL framework, called Egalitarian Fair Federated Learning (EFFL), that aims to achieve an egalitarian fair global model that provides both high performance and egalitarian fairness for clients; ❷ We formally define the learning goals in EFFL and form it as a multi-constrained multi-objectives optimization (MCMOO) problem. As shown in Fig. 1 (b), the objectives are to minimize the local empirical risk losses {l1,…,lN}subscript𝑙1…subscript𝑙𝑁\left\{l_{1},...,l_{N}\right\} on N𝑁N clients (goal 1). The local decision biases {f1,…,fN}subscript𝑓1…subscript𝑓𝑁\left\{f_{1},...,f_{N}\right\} on N𝑁N clients are constrained to be below an acceptable bias budget (goal 2). These two goals jointly ensure higher model performance across clients. We impose constraints on the deviations of local empirical risk loss and local decision bias from their mean values (goal 3 and goal 4) to achieve egalitarian fairness with equal performance among clients; ❸ To address the challenges mentioned above, we propose a three-stage gradient-based algorithm that achieves Pareto optimal solutions in the decision space defined by the decision bias and egalitarian fairness constraints, where the global model performance on each local client is maximized and cannot be further improved without harming others; ❹ We perform comprehensive experiments on both synthetic and real-world datasets and show that our proposed EFFL framework can achieve a global model that outperforms state-of-the-art (SOTA) baselines in terms of both performance and egalitarian fairness across clients.

2 Related Work

Most of the existing fairness research (Roh et al., 2021; Shen et al., 2022; Choi et al., 2021; Sankar et al., 2021) assumes that the training process can access the whole training dataset in a centralized manner. However, this assumption does not hold in real-world scenarios where data privacy and communication constraints prevent clients from sharing their data with a central server. In FL, some work (Ezzeldin et al., 2023; Papadaki et al., 2022; Chu et al., 2021; Du et al., 2021; Cui et al., 2021) aims to reduce model outcome bias towards different protected groups such as gender, race, or age. Recently, there has been a growing interest in achieving fairness towards clients in FL. Mohri et al. (2019) propose AFL, a min-max optimization scheme that focuses on the worst-performing client. Li et al. (2021) propose Ditto to achieve training fairness by allowing clients to fine-tune the received global model using local data. Cui et al. (2021) propose FCFL to jointly consider accuracy consistency and decision bias across different local clients (data sources) by minimizing the model loss of the worst-performing client. These works enhance a fair representation of different clients during training but cannot guarantee equal performance. To achieve equal accuracy across clients, Li et al. (2019) propose q-FFL, a heuristic method that adjusts the weights of the aggregate process to enhance the influence of poorer individuals. Pan et al. (2023) propose FedMDFG that adds cosine similarity between the loss vectors among clients and the unit vector as a fairness objective in the local loss functions. Previous work overlooks the trade-offs in achieving equality from a social welfare perspective and local optimality from an individual beneficial perspective. Moreover, as there is an inherent trade-off between accuracy and decision bias for each client (Wang et al., 2021), we also need to consider the deterioration of the decision bias caused by accuracy distribution adjustment. It is necessary to ensure that the decision bias of each individual is within an acceptable budget to provide a trustworthy global model. For the same social welfare purpose as accuracy equality, maintaining decision bias equality among individuals is helpful to improve the reputation and decision credibility of poor clients. We argue that optimizing the accuracy objective alone is insufficient for an FL system that adheres to social ethics and legal regulations. Therefore, we introduce a novel FL framework, EFFL, to produce a global model with high and equitable performance across clients.

3 Preliminaries

In this section, we provide the notions and formally define the problem of Egalitarian Fairness Federated Learning (EFFL), which extends the fairness criteria in FL and covers novel application scenarios.

3.1 Federated Learning

We focus on horizontal FL(Yang et al., 2019), which involves N𝑁N clients, each associated with a specific dataset 𝒟k={Xk,Ak,Yk}subscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝐴𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}=\{X_{k},A_{k},Y_{k}\}, where k∈{1,…,N}𝑘1…𝑁k\in\left\{1,...,N\right\}, Xksubscript𝑋𝑘X_{k} denotes the general attributes of the data without protected information, Aksubscript𝐴𝑘A_{k} denote a protected attribute, such as gender, race, or religion, and Yksubscript𝑌𝑘Y_{k} denoted truth label. The FL procedure involves multiple rounds of communication between the server and the clients. In each round, the server sends the global model hθsubscriptℎ𝜃h_{\theta} with parameter θ𝜃\theta to the clients, who then train their local models on their local private datasets {𝒟1,…,𝒟N}subscript𝒟1…subscript𝒟𝑁\left\{\mathcal{D}_{1},...,\mathcal{D}_{N}\right\}, resulting in local models {hθ1,…,hθN}subscriptℎsubscript𝜃1…subscriptℎsubscript𝜃𝑁\left\{h_{\theta_{1}},...,h_{\theta_{N}}\right\}.The server then aggregates the local parameters and updates the global model for the next communication round (McMahan et al., 2017). The original FL (McMahan et al., 2017) aims to minimize the average empirical risk loss over all the clients’ datasets, and the optimal hypothesis parameter θ∗superscript𝜃{\theta^{*}} satisfies:

θ∗=arg⁡minθ∈Θ​∑k=1N(|𝒟k|∑k=1N|𝒟k|​lk​(Y^k,Yk)),superscript𝜃subscript𝜃Θsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝒟𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑙𝑘subscript^𝑌𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘\theta^{*}=\arg\,\,\min_{\theta\in\Theta}\sum_{k=1}^{N}\left(\frac{\left|\mathcal{D}_{k}\right|}{{\textstyle\sum_{k=1}^{N}\left|\mathcal{D}_{k}\right|}}l_{k}\left(\hat{Y}_{k},Y_{k}\right)\right), (1)

where Y^k=hθ​(Xk,Ak)subscript^𝑌𝑘subscriptℎ𝜃subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝐴𝑘\hat{Y}_{k}=h_{\theta}\left(X_{k},{A}_{k}\right) is the output of the hypothesis hθsubscriptℎ𝜃h_{\theta} when input (Xk,Ak)subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝐴𝑘\left(X_{k},{A}_{k}\right) and lk​(⋅)subscript𝑙𝑘⋅l_{k}(\cdot) is the loss function for k𝑘k-th client.

3.2 Model Performance Metrics

As mentioned in Sec. 1, we study egalitarian fairness in terms of two aspects of model performance: accuracy and decision bias. The local accuracy of the global model on the k𝑘k-th client is naturally controlled by the training loss lksubscript𝑙𝑘l_{k}, which measures the difference between the model’s decision and the truth label on the local data of the k𝑘k-th client. In the context of classification, we use the following BCELoss on the k𝑘k-th client:

BCELoss: ​lk​(h)=−1|Y|​∑i=1|Y|(Yki​log⁡(Y^ki)+(1−Yki)​log⁡(1−Y^ki)).BCELoss: subscript𝑙𝑘ℎ1𝑌superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑌superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript^𝑌𝑘𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑘𝑖1superscriptsubscript^𝑌𝑘𝑖\text{BCELoss:\,\,}l_{k}(h)=-\frac{1}{\left|Y\right|}\sum_{i=1}^{\left|Y\right|}\left(Y_{k}^{i}\log\left(\hat{Y}_{k}^{i}\right)+\left(1-Y_{k}^{i}\right)\log\left(1-\hat{Y}_{k}^{i}\right)\right). (2)

Decision bias refers to the disparities in model decisions made across different groups formed by protected attributes, such as gender, race, and region. We use two decision bias metrics, namely Accuracy Parity Standard Deviation (APSD) and True positive rate Parity Standard Deviation (TPSD)(Poulain et al., 2023). Taking a binary classification problem as example, the decision bias measured by APSD or TPSD for the k𝑘k-th client are defined as follows:

APSD: ​fk​(h)=∑i=1M(Pr⁡(Y^k=1∣Ak=i)−μ)2M,matrixAPSD: subscript𝑓𝑘ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀superscriptPrsubscript^𝑌𝑘conditional1subscript𝐴𝑘𝑖𝜇2𝑀\begin{matrix}\text{APSD:\,\,}f_{k}\left(h\right)=\sqrt{\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{M}\left(\operatorname{Pr}\left(\hat{Y}_{k}=1\mid A_{k}=i\right)-\mu\right)^{2}}{M}},\end{matrix} (3)
TPSD: ​fk​(h)=∑i=1M(Pr⁡(Y^k=1∣Ak=i,Yk=1)−μ)2M,matrixTPSD: subscript𝑓𝑘ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀superscriptPrsubscript^𝑌𝑘conditional1subscript𝐴𝑘𝑖subscript𝑌𝑘1𝜇2𝑀\begin{matrix}\text{TPSD:\,\,}f_{k}\left(h\right)=\sqrt{\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{M}\left(\operatorname{Pr}\left(\hat{Y}_{k}=1\mid A_{k}=i,Y_{k}=1\right)-\mu\right)^{2}}{M}},\end{matrix} (4)

where μ𝜇\mu is the average True Positive Rate (TPR) or accuracy under all groups divided by the values of the protected attribute, and M𝑀M is the number of possible values for the sensitive attribute Aksubscript𝐴𝑘A_{k}. A hypothesis hθsubscriptℎ𝜃h_{\theta} satisfies ϵbsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\epsilon_{b}-decision bias on k𝑘k-th client if fk​(h)≤ϵbsubscript𝑓𝑘ℎsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏f_{k}(h)\leq\epsilon_{b}, where ϵbsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\epsilon_{b} is the predefined budget for the decision bias.

3.3 Egalitarian fairness in FL

Egalitarian fairness in FL refers to the model providing equal performance across clients, roughly speaking, ensuring clients have levels of performance that are all roughly comparable. Therefore, we evaluate egalitarian fairness in FL based on the degree of equality in performance. In existing work, Pan et al. (2023) measured the performance equality by the cosine similarity between the model losses on all clients [l1,…,lN]subscript𝑙1…subscript𝑙𝑁\left[l_{1},...,l_{N}\right] and the unit vector p=𝟏𝑝1p=\mathbf{1}. This metric fails to distinguish each client’s performance and to impose precise constraints on them, especially when the demand for performance equality is dynamic. For instance, clients may allow the violation of performance equality to be within an acceptable threshold. To avoid this, we measure the model performance equality across clients by the absolute deviation of each client’s performance from the mean performance of all clients. A hypothesis hℎh satisfies ϵv​lsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙\epsilon_{vl}-egalitarian fairness on accuracy performance and ϵv​bsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏\epsilon_{vb}-egalitarian fairness on decision bias performance if:

|lk​(h)−l¯​(h)|≤ϵv​l,|fk​(h)−f¯​(h)|≤ϵv​b,k∈{1,…,N}.matrixformulae-sequencesubscript𝑙𝑘ℎ¯𝑙ℎsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙formulae-sequencesubscript𝑓𝑘ℎ¯𝑓ℎsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏𝑘1…𝑁\begin{matrix}\left|l_{k}(h)-\bar{l}(h)\right|\leq\epsilon_{vl},\left|f_{k}(h)-\bar{f}(h)\right|\leq\epsilon_{vb},k\in\left\{1,...,N\right\}.\end{matrix} (5)

where l¯​(h)=1N​∑k=1Nlk​(h)¯𝑙ℎ1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑙𝑘ℎ\bar{l}(h)=\frac{1}{N}{\textstyle\sum_{k=1}^{N}l_{k}(h)} and f¯​(h)=1N​∑k=1Nfk​(h)¯𝑓ℎ1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑓𝑘ℎ\bar{f}(h)=\frac{1}{N}{\textstyle\sum_{k=1}^{N}f_{k}(h)} are the average empirical risk loss and average decision bias, respectively, and ϵv​lsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙\epsilon_{vl} and ϵv​bsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏\epsilon_{vb} are the predefined budgets for the egalitarian fairness on accuracy and decision bias, respectively.

3.4 Egalitarian Fairness Federated Learning

To achieve a global model that provides both high and equal performance across clients, we propose a novel framework called Egalitarian Fair Federated Learning (EFFL), in which the training goals can be formulated as a multi-constrained multi-objectives optimization (MCMOO) problem.

Definition 1

(Egalitarian Fairness Federated Learning) We formalize the Egalitarian Fair Federated Learning (EFFL) problem as follows:

minh∈ℋ∗​{l1​(h),…,lN​(h)},s.t.​{fk​(h)}k=1N≤ϵb,{|lk​(h)−l¯​(h)|}k=1N≤ϵv​l,{|fk​(h)−f¯​(h)|}k=1N≤ϵv​b,matrixℎsuperscriptℋsubscript𝑙1ℎ…subscript𝑙𝑁ℎformulae-sequences.t.superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘ℎ𝑘1𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑙𝑘ℎ¯𝑙ℎ𝑘1𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘ℎ¯𝑓ℎ𝑘1𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏\begin{matrix}\underset{h\in\mathcal{H}^{*}}{\min}\left\{l_{1}\left(h\right),...,l_{N}\left(h\right)\right\},\\ \text{s.t.}\left\{f_{k}\left(h\right)\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{b},\left\{\left|l_{k}\left(h\right)-\bar{l}(h)\right|\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{vl},\left\{\left|f_{k}\left(h\right)-\bar{f}(h)\right|\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{vb},\end{matrix} (6)

where hℎh is a hypothesis from a hypothesis set ℋ∗superscriptℋ\mathcal{H}^{*}.

The MCMOO problem seeks to minimize the empirical risk losses for all clients while ensuring each client has a ϵbsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\epsilon_{b}-decision bias. It also satisfies ϵv​lsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙\epsilon_{vl}-egalitarian fairness for accuracy and ϵv​bsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏\epsilon_{vb}-egalitarian fairness for decision bias. Finding the optimal solution to the MCMOO problem is nontrivial as the objectives may be conflicting. Therefore, we aim to identify the Pareto-optimal hypothesis hℎh, which is not dominated by any other h′∈ℋsuperscriptℎ′ℋh^{\prime}\in\mathcal{H}. The definitions of Pareto optimal and Pareto front are as follows:

Definition 2

(Pareto Optimal and Pareto Front (Lin et al., 2019)) In a multi-objective optimization problem with loss function l​(h)={l1​(h),…,lN​(h)}𝑙ℎsubscript𝑙1ℎ…subscript𝑙𝑁ℎl(h)=\left\{l_{1}(h),...,l_{N}(h)\right\}, we say that for h1,h2∈ℋsubscriptℎ1subscriptℎ2ℋh_{1},h_{2}\in\mathcal{H}, h1subscriptℎ1h_{1} is dominated by h2subscriptℎ2h_{2} if ∀i∈[N],li​(h2)≤li​(h1)formulae-sequencefor-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑁subscript𝑙𝑖subscriptℎ2subscript𝑙𝑖subscriptℎ1\forall i\in\left[N\right],l_{i}(h_{2})\leq l_{i}(h_{1}) and ∃i∈[N],li​(h2)<li​(h1)formulae-sequence𝑖delimited-[]𝑁subscript𝑙𝑖subscriptℎ2subscript𝑙𝑖subscriptℎ1\exists i\in\left[N\right],l_{i}(h_{2})<l_{i}(h_{1}). A solution hℎh is Pareto optimal if it is not dominated by any other h′∈ℋsuperscriptℎ′ℋh^{\prime}\in\mathcal{H}. The collection of Pareto optimal solutions is called the Pareto set. The image of the Pareto set in the loss function space is called the Pareto front.

4 Three-Stage Optimization Approach for EFFL

4.1 Optimization Path to Obtain Pareto Optimal

Fig. 2 illustrates the feasible decision space of EFFL, which is bounded by the intersection of two hypothesis sets: ℋBsubscriptℋ𝐵\mathcal{H}_{B} containing all hypothesis satisfy the ϵbsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\epsilon_{b}-decision bias constraint, and ℋEsubscriptℋ𝐸\mathcal{H}_{E} containing all hypothesis satisfy the ϵv​lsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙\epsilon_{vl}-egalitarian fairness on accuracy and ϵv​bsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏\epsilon_{vb}-egalitarian fairness on decision bias. We aim to search the Pareto set ℋ∗superscriptℋ\mathcal{H}^{*} for the objectives in Eq. 6 within the feasible decision space. The properties of the hypothesis sets are as follows: (1) The ℋBsubscriptℋ𝐵\mathcal{H}_{B} contains hypotheses satisfying ϵbsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\epsilon_{b}-decision bias in each client,

{fk​(h)}k=1N≤ϵb,∀h∈ℋB.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘ℎ𝑘1𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏for-allℎsubscriptℋ𝐵\left\{f_{k}\left(h\right)\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{b},\forall h\in\mathcal{H}_{B}. (7)

(2) The ℋEsubscriptℋ𝐸\mathcal{H}_{E} contains hypotheses that satisfy ϵv​lsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙\epsilon_{vl}-egalitarian fairness on accuracy and ϵv​bsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏\epsilon_{vb}-egalitarian fairness on decision bias across all clients,

{|lk​(h)−l¯​(h)|}k=1N≤ϵv​l,{|fk​(h)−f¯​(h)|}k=1N≤ϵv​b,∀h∈ℋE.matrixformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑙𝑘ℎ¯𝑙ℎ𝑘1𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘ℎ¯𝑓ℎ𝑘1𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏for-allℎsubscriptℋ𝐸\begin{matrix}\left\{\left|l_{k}\left(h\right)-\bar{l}\left(h\right)\right|\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{vl},\left\{\left|f_{k}\left(h\right)-\bar{f}\left(h\right)\right|\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{vb},\forall h\in\mathcal{H}_{E}.\end{matrix} (8)

(3) The ℋ∗⊂ℋB∩ℋEsuperscriptℋsubscriptℋ𝐵subscriptℋ𝐸\mathcal{H}^{*}\subset\mathcal{H}_{B}\cap\mathcal{H}_{E} is the Pareto set of EFFL in Eq. 6, i.e.,

h′⊀h,∀h∈ℋ∗,∀h′∈ℋB∩ℋE.formulae-sequencenot-precedessuperscriptℎ′ℎformulae-sequencefor-allℎsuperscriptℋfor-allsuperscriptℎ′subscriptℋ𝐵subscriptℋ𝐸h^{\prime}\not\prec h,\forall h\in\mathcal{H}^{*},\forall h^{\prime}\in\mathcal{H}_{B}\cap\mathcal{H}_{E}. (9)

Finding Pareto set for EFFL is nontrivial as the feasible decision space is highly restricted. Moreover, when the number of objectives N𝑁N is large, optimizing one objective may adversely affect other objectives. We construct an approximate Pareto front by linear scalarization technique. Average weights are applied to each objective and combine N𝑁N-objectives into a single surrogate objective. The surrogate objective forms the convex part of the Pareto front, as shown in Fig. 2, which is denoted as ℋL¯subscriptℋ¯𝐿\mathcal{H}_{\bar{L}}. The hypothesis in the ℋL¯subscriptℋ¯𝐿\mathcal{H}_{\bar{L}} satisfies:

l¯​(h)≤l¯​(h′),∀h∈ℋL¯,h′∉ℋL¯.formulae-sequence¯𝑙ℎ¯𝑙superscriptℎ′formulae-sequencefor-allℎsubscriptℋ¯𝐿superscriptℎ′subscriptℋ¯𝐿\bar{l}\left(h\right)\leq\bar{l}\left(h^{\prime}\right),\forall h\in\mathcal{H}_{\bar{L}},h^{\prime}\notin\mathcal{H}_{\bar{L}}. (10)

Compared to ℋ∗superscriptℋ\mathcal{H}^{*}, ℋL¯subscriptℋ¯𝐿\mathcal{H}_{\bar{L}} is easier to obtain and can serve as an intermediate set, from which we propose a three-stage optimization algorithm with an optimal path: h0→ℋB∩ℋL¯→ℋB∩ℋE∩ℋL¯→ℋ∗→superscriptℎ0subscriptℋ𝐵subscriptℋ¯𝐿→subscriptℋ𝐵subscriptℋ𝐸subscriptℋ¯𝐿→superscriptℋh^{0}\rightarrow\mathcal{H}_{B}\cap\mathcal{H}_{\bar{L}}\rightarrow\mathcal{H}_{B}\cap\mathcal{H}_{E}\cap\mathcal{H}_{\bar{L}}\rightarrow\mathcal{H}^{*} (purple arrows in Fig. 2), and decompose the EFFL problem into three sub-problems as follows:

Stage 1: Constrained Minimization Problem. We define a constrained minimization problem on the hypothesis set ℋℋ\mathcal{H} to obtain a hypothesis h′∈ℋB∩ℋL¯superscriptℎ′subscriptℋ𝐵subscriptℋ¯𝐿h^{\prime}\in\mathcal{H}_{B}\cap\mathcal{H}_{\bar{L}},

minh∈ℋ​l¯​(h),s.t.​{fk​(h)}k=1N≤ϵb.ℎℋ¯𝑙ℎs.t.superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘ℎ𝑘1𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\underset{h\in\mathcal{H}}{\min}\,\,\bar{l}\left(h\right),\text{s.t.}\left\{f_{k}\left(h\right)\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{b}. (11)

By solving Eq. 11, we obtain h′superscriptℎ′h^{\prime} that 1) satisfies ϵbsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\epsilon_{b}-decision bias for each client and 2) minimizes the average empirical risk loss among all clients.

Stage 2: Multi-Constrained Optimization Problem. We formulate a multi-constrained optimization problem to obtain a hypothesis h′′∈ℋB∩ℋE∩ℋL¯superscriptℎ′′subscriptℋ𝐵subscriptℋ𝐸subscriptℋ¯𝐿h^{\prime\prime}\in\mathcal{H}_{B}\cap\mathcal{H}_{E}\cap\mathcal{H}_{\bar{L}},

minh∈ℋ​l¯​(h),s.t.​{|lk​(h)−l¯​(h)|}k=1N≤ϵv​l,{|fk​(h)−f¯​(h)|}k=1N≤ϵv​b,{fk​(h)}k=1N≤ϵb.matrixformulae-sequenceℎℋ¯𝑙ℎs.t.superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑙𝑘ℎ¯𝑙ℎ𝑘1𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘ℎ¯𝑓ℎ𝑘1𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘ℎ𝑘1𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\begin{matrix}\underset{h\in\mathcal{H}}{\min}\,\,\bar{l}\left(h\right),\text{s.t.}\left\{\left|l_{k}\left(h\right)-\bar{l}\left(h\right)\right|\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{vl},\left\{\left|f_{k}\left(h\right)-\bar{f}\left(h\right)\right|\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{vb},\left\{f_{k}\left(h\right)\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{b}.\end{matrix} (12)

By solving Eq. 12, we obtain h′′superscriptℎ′′h^{\prime\prime} that, compared to h′superscriptℎ′h^{\prime}, exhibits the following properties: 1) it provides ϵv​lsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙\epsilon_{vl}-egalitarian fairness on accuracy; and 2) it provides ϵv​bsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏\epsilon_{vb}-egalitarian fairness on decision bias.

Stage 3: Multi-Constrained Pareto Optimization Problem. Focusing solely on minimizing weighted sum l¯​(h)¯𝑙ℎ\bar{l}(h) during optimization may harm individual clients. To address this issue, we formulate a multi-constrained Pareto optimization problem to further optimize h′′superscriptℎ′′h^{\prime\prime} to h∗∈ℋ∗superscriptℎsuperscriptℋh^{*}\in\mathcal{H}^{*}, where the empirical risk loss of each client is further reduced until Pareto optimality is achieved. At this point, the loss of each client cannot be further minimized without adversely affecting the loss of other clients,

minh∈ℋ​{l1​(h),…,lN​(h)},s.t.​{fk​(h)}k=1N≤ϵb,{|lk​(h)−l¯​(h)|}k=1N≤ϵv​l,{|fk​(h)−f¯​(h)|}k=1N≤ϵv​b,l¯​(h)≤l¯​(h′′).matrixformulae-sequenceℎℋsubscript𝑙1ℎ…subscript𝑙𝑁ℎs.t.superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘ℎ𝑘1𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑙𝑘ℎ¯𝑙ℎ𝑘1𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘ℎ¯𝑓ℎ𝑘1𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏¯𝑙ℎ¯𝑙superscriptℎ′′\begin{matrix}\underset{h\in\mathcal{H}}{\min}\,\,\left\{l_{1}\left(h\right),...,{l}_{N}\left(h\right)\right\},\text{s.t.}\left\{f_{k}\left(h\right)\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{b},\left\{\left|l_{k}\left(h\right)-\bar{l}\left(h\right)\right|\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{vl},\\ \left\{\left|f_{k}\left(h\right)-\bar{f}\left(h\right)\right|\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{vb},\bar{l}\left(h\right)\leq\bar{l}\left(h^{\prime\prime}\right).\end{matrix} (13)

4.2 Three-Stage Optimization for obtaining ℋ∗superscriptℋ\mathcal{H}^{*}

To obtain the convergent solution of the sub-problems defined in Eq. 11∼similar-to\simEq. 13, we propose a gradient-based algorithm for obtaining h∗∈ℋ∗superscriptℎsuperscriptℋh^{*}\in\mathcal{H}^{*}, which is suitable for the implementation under FL. Given a hypothesis hθtsubscriptℎsuperscript𝜃𝑡h_{\theta^{t}} parameterized by θtsuperscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{t}. At iteration t+1𝑡1t+1, the update rule of gradient-based methods is θt+1=θt+η​dsuperscript𝜃𝑡1superscript𝜃𝑡𝜂𝑑\theta^{t+1}=\theta^{t}+\eta d, where d𝑑d is a gradient descent direction and η𝜂\eta is the step size. In the case of an optimization problem with N𝑁N objectives, i.e., min⁡{l1​(hθ),…,lN​(hθ)}subscript𝑙1subscriptℎ𝜃…subscript𝑙𝑁subscriptℎ𝜃\min\left\{l_{1}(h_{\theta}),...,l_{N}(h_{\theta})\right\}, a gradient d𝑑d is efficient to make the optimization proceed towards minimization if {d∗T​∇θli​(hθ)}i=1N≤0superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑑absent𝑇subscript∇𝜃subscript𝑙𝑖subscriptℎ𝜃𝑖1𝑁0\left\{d^{*T}\nabla_{\theta}l_{i}\left(h_{\theta}\right)\right\}_{i=1}^{N}\leq 0. As the gradient direction d𝑑d resides within the convex hull of the gradients of all objectives and constraints, denoted as G=[∇θl1​(hθ),…,∇θlN​(hθ)]𝐺subscript∇𝜃subscript𝑙1subscriptℎ𝜃…subscript∇𝜃subscript𝑙𝑁subscriptℎ𝜃G=\left[\nabla_{\theta}l_{1}(h_{\theta}),...,\nabla_{\theta}l_{N}(h_{\theta})\right] (Désidéri, 2012), we can obtain a gradient descent direction d∗superscript𝑑d^{*} by performing a linear transformation on G𝐺G using an N𝑁N-dimensional vector α∗superscript𝛼\alpha^{*},

d∗=α∗T​G,where​α∗=arg⁡min𝛼​‖∑i=1Nαi​∇θli​(hθ)‖,s.t. ​∑i=1Nαi=1,αi≥0,∀i∈[N].matrixformulae-sequencesuperscript𝑑superscript𝛼absent𝑇𝐺wheresuperscript𝛼𝛼normsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝛼𝑖subscript∇𝜃subscript𝑙𝑖subscriptℎ𝜃formulae-sequences.t. superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝛼𝑖1formulae-sequencesubscript𝛼𝑖0for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑁\begin{matrix}d^{*}=\alpha^{*T}G,\,\,\mathrm{where}\,\,\alpha^{*}=\arg\,\underset{\alpha}{\min}\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{N}\alpha_{i}\nabla_{\theta}l_{i}\left(h_{\theta}\right)\right\|,\\ \text{s.t. }\,\,\sum_{i=1}^{N}\alpha_{i}=1,\alpha_{i}\geq 0,\forall i\in\left[N\right].\end{matrix} (14)

Solution for Stage 1. We first transform Eq. 11 into an equivalent single-constraint optimization problem by imposing constraint only on the max-value as follows,

minh∈ℋl¯(h),s.t.max{fk(h)}k=1N≤ϵb.\underset{h\in\mathcal{H}}{\min}\,\,\bar{l}\left(h\right),\,\,\text{s.t.}\,\,\max\left\{f_{k}\left(h\right)\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{b}. (15)

Denoting the max{fk(h)}k=1N\max\left\{f_{k}\left(h\right)\right\}_{k=1}^{N} as fm​a​x​(h)subscript𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎf_{max}(h), the descent gradient of Eq. 15 lies in the convex hull of G′=[∇θl¯​(h),∇θfm​a​x​(h)]superscript𝐺′subscript∇𝜃¯𝑙ℎsubscript∇𝜃subscript𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎG^{\prime}=\left[\nabla_{\theta}\bar{l}(h),\nabla_{\theta}f_{max}(h)\right]. We employ an alternating optimization strategy: if the ϵbsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\epsilon_{b}-decision bias is satisfied within the worst-case client, only l¯​(h)¯𝑙ℎ\bar{l}(h) is further optimized,

d∗=arg⁡mind∈G′​dT​∇θl¯​(h),if​fm​a​x​(h)≤ϵb.formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑑𝑑superscript𝐺′superscript𝑑𝑇subscript∇𝜃¯𝑙ℎifsubscript𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏d^{*}=\arg\,\underset{d\in G^{\prime}}{\min}\,\,d^{T}\nabla_{\theta}\bar{l}(h),\,\,\text{if}\,\,f_{max}(h)\leq\epsilon_{b}. (16)

Otherwise, we optimize towards a descent direction d𝑑d, which minimizes fm​a​x​(h)subscript𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎf_{max}(h) while ensuring that l¯​(h)¯𝑙ℎ\bar{l}(h) does not increase, as follows:

d∗=arg⁡mind∈G′​dT​∇θfm​a​x​(h),s.t.​dT​∇θl¯​(h)≤0,if​fm​a​x​(h)>ϵb.formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑑𝑑superscript𝐺′superscript𝑑𝑇subscript∇𝜃subscript𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎformulae-sequences.t.superscript𝑑𝑇subscript∇𝜃¯𝑙ℎ0ifsubscript𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏d^{*}=\arg\,\underset{d\in G^{\prime}}{\min}\,\,d^{T}\nabla_{\theta}f_{max}(h),\,\,\text{s.t.}\,\,d^{T}\nabla_{\theta}\bar{l}(h)\leq 0,\,\,\text{if}\,\,f_{max}(h)>\epsilon_{b}. (17)

The gradient direction in Eq. 16 and Eq. 17 is optimized towards to reduce the loss while satisfying the ϵb−limit-fromsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\epsilon_{b}-decision bias constraint better, leading to a hypothesis h′superscriptℎ′h^{\prime} that balances the trade-off between loss and decision bias.

Solution for Stage 2. To reduce the computational complexity of handling O​(N)𝑂𝑁O(N)-constraints in Eq. 12, we optimize the egalitarian fairness for the worst-case client. Moreover, to better achieve ϵv​l−limit-fromsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙\epsilon_{vl}-egalitarian fairness on accuracy and ϵv​b−limit-fromsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏\epsilon_{vb}-egalitarian fairness on decision bias, we modify Eq. 12 by treating egalitarian fairness as objectives and applying a constraint l¯​(h)≤l¯​(h′)¯𝑙ℎ¯𝑙superscriptℎ′\bar{l}\left(h\right)\leq\bar{l}\left(h^{\prime}\right) to avoid the degradation of model performance. We optimize egalitarian fairness of accuracy and decision bias alternately, i.e., if {|lk​(h)−l¯​(h)|}k=1N≤ϵv​lsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑙𝑘ℎ¯𝑙ℎ𝑘1𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙\left\{\left|l_{k}\left(h\right)-\bar{l}\left(h\right)\right|\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{vl},

minh∈ℋmax{|fk(h)−f¯(h)|−ϵv​b}k=1N,s.t.max{fk(h)}k=1N≤ϵb,l¯(h)≤l¯(h′),\begin{matrix}\underset{h\in\mathcal{H}}{\min}\max\left\{\left|f_{k}\left(h\right)-\bar{f}(h)\right|-\epsilon_{vb}\right\}_{k=1}^{N},\,\,\text{s.t.}\,\,\max\left\{f_{k}(h)\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{b},\bar{l}\left(h\right)\leq\bar{l}\left(h^{\prime}\right),\end{matrix} (18)

else,

minh∈ℋmax{|lk(h)−l¯(h)|−ϵv​l}k=1N,s.t.max{|fk(h)−f¯(h)|}k=1N≤ϵv​b,max{fk(h)}k=1N≤ϵb,l¯(h)≤l¯(h′).\begin{matrix}\underset{h\in\mathcal{H}}{\min}\max\left\{\left|l_{k}\left(h\right)-\bar{l}(h)\right|-\epsilon_{vl}\right\}_{k=1}^{N},\\ \text{s.t.}\,\,\max\left\{\left|f_{k}\left(h\right)-\bar{f}(h)\right|\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{vb},\max\left\{f_{k}(h)\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{b},\bar{l}\left(h\right)\leq\bar{l}\left(h^{\prime}\right).\end{matrix} (19)

Denoting the max{|lk(h)−l¯(h)|−ϵv​l}k=1N\max\left\{\left|l_{k}\left(h\right)-\bar{l}(h)\right|-\epsilon_{vl}\right\}_{k=1}^{N} and max{|fk(h)−f¯(h)|−ϵv​b}k=1N\max\left\{\left|f_{k}\left(h\right)-\bar{f}(h)\right|-\epsilon_{vb}\right\}_{k=1}^{N} as l^m​a​x​(h)subscript^𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎ\hat{l}_{max}(h) and f^m​a​x​(h)subscript^𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎ\hat{f}_{max}(h), respectively, the gradient descent direction of Eq. 18 lies in the convex hull of G′′=[∇θf^m​a​x,∇θfm​a​x,∇θl¯]superscript𝐺′′subscript∇𝜃subscript^𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript∇𝜃subscript𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript∇𝜃¯𝑙G^{\prime\prime}=\left[\nabla_{\theta}\hat{f}_{max},\nabla_{\theta}f_{max},\nabla_{\theta}\bar{l}\right]. We obtain the optimal d∗superscript𝑑d^{*} as follows:

d∗=arg⁡mind∈G′′​dT​∇θf^m​a​x​(h),s.t.​dT​∇θl¯​(h)≤0,dT​∇θfm​a​x​(h)≤0​ if​fm​a​x​(h)>ϵb.matrixformulae-sequencesuperscript𝑑𝑑superscript𝐺′′superscript𝑑𝑇subscript∇𝜃subscript^𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎformulae-sequences.t.superscript𝑑𝑇subscript∇𝜃¯𝑙ℎ0superscript𝑑𝑇subscript∇𝜃subscript𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎ0 ifsubscript𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\begin{matrix}d^{*}=\arg\underset{d\in G^{\prime\prime}}{\min}d^{T}\nabla_{\theta}\hat{f}_{max}(h),\text{s.t.}\,\,d^{T}\nabla_{\theta}\bar{l}(h)\leq 0,d^{T}\nabla_{\theta}f_{max}(h)\leq 0\,\,\text{ if}\,\,f_{max}(h)>\epsilon_{b}.\end{matrix} (20)

The gradient descent direction of Eq. 19 lies in the convex hull of G′′=[∇θl^m​a​x,∇θf^m​a​x,∇θfm​a​x,∇θl¯]superscript𝐺′′subscript∇𝜃subscript^𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript∇𝜃subscript^𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript∇𝜃subscript𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript∇𝜃¯𝑙G^{\prime\prime}=\left[\nabla_{\theta}\hat{l}_{max},\nabla_{\theta}\hat{f}_{max},\nabla_{\theta}f_{max},\nabla_{\theta}\bar{l}\right]. We obtain the optimal d∗superscript𝑑d^{*} as follows:

d∗=arg⁡mind∈G′′​dT​∇θl^m​a​x​(h),s.t.​dT​∇θl¯​(h)≤0,dT​∇θf^m​a​x​(h)≤0​ if​f^m​a​x​(h)>ϵv​b,dT​∇θfm​a​x​(h)≤0​ if​fm​a​x​(h)>ϵb.matrixformulae-sequencesuperscript𝑑𝑑superscript𝐺′′superscript𝑑𝑇subscript∇𝜃subscript^𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎs.t.superscript𝑑𝑇subscript∇𝜃¯𝑙ℎ0formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑑𝑇subscript∇𝜃subscript^𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎ0 ifsubscript^𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏superscript𝑑𝑇subscript∇𝜃subscript𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎ0 ifsubscript𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\begin{matrix}d^{*}=\arg\underset{d\in G^{\prime\prime}}{\min}d^{T}\nabla_{\theta}\hat{l}_{max}(h),\text{s.t.}\,\,d^{T}\nabla_{\theta}\bar{l}(h)\leq 0,\\ d^{T}\nabla_{\theta}\hat{f}_{max}(h)\leq 0\,\,\text{ if}\,\,\hat{f}_{max}(h)>\epsilon_{vb},\,\,d^{T}\nabla_{\theta}f_{max}(h)\leq 0\,\,\text{ if}\,\,f_{max}(h)>\epsilon_{b}.\end{matrix} (21)

The constraints are dynamically imposed, depending on whether the current hypotheses hℎh satisfies ϵbsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\epsilon_{b}-decision bias and ϵv​bsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏\epsilon_{vb}-egalitarian fairness on the decision bias. The optimal gradient direction in Eq. 20 and Eq. 21 is optimized towards improving the equality of performance among clients without causing the degradation of model performance, leading to a hypothesis h′′superscriptℎ′′h^{\prime\prime} that balances the trade-off between egalitarian fairness and maximizing model performance.

Solution for Stage 3. To reduce the computational complexity of minimizing N𝑁N objectives and handling O​(N)𝑂𝑁O(N)-constraints in Eq. 13, we optimize the empirical risk loss for the worst-case client and impose constraints lk​(h)≤lk​(h′′)subscript𝑙𝑘ℎsubscript𝑙𝑘superscriptℎ′′l_{k}\left(h\right)\leq l_{k}\left(h^{\prime\prime}\right) to prevent the degradation of performance for other clients.

minh∈ℋ​max⁡{l1​(h),…,lN​(h)},s.t.​lk​(h)≤lk​(h′′),∀k∈[N],l¯​(h)≤l¯​(h′′),max{|fk(h)|}k=1N≤ϵb,max{|lk(h)−l¯(h)|}k=1N≤ϵv​l,max{|fk(h)−f¯(h)|}k=1N≤ϵv​b.\begin{matrix}\underset{h\in\mathcal{H}}{\min}\max\left\{l_{1}\left(h\right),...,{l}_{N}\left(h\right)\right\},\text{s.t.}\,\,l_{k}(h)\leq l_{k}(h^{\prime\prime}),\forall k\in[N],\bar{l}(h)\leq\bar{l}(h^{\prime\prime}),\\ \max\left\{\left|f_{k}\left(h\right)\right|\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{b},\max\left\{\left|l_{k}\left(h\right)-\bar{l}(h)\right|\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{vl},\max\left\{\left|f_{k}\left(h\right)-\bar{f}(h)\right|\right\}_{k=1}^{N}\leq\epsilon_{vb}.\end{matrix} (22)

Denoting the max{lk(h)}k=1N\max\left\{l_{k}\left(h\right)\right\}_{k=1}^{N} as lm​a​x​(h)subscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎl_{max}(h), the gradient descent direction lies in the convex hull of G∗=[∇θlm​a​x​(h),∇θl1​(h),…,∇θlN​(h),∇θl¯​(h),∇θfm​a​x​(h),∇θl^m​a​x​(h),∇θf^m​a​x​(h)]superscript𝐺subscript∇𝜃subscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎsubscript∇𝜃subscript𝑙1ℎ…subscript∇𝜃subscript𝑙𝑁ℎsubscript∇𝜃¯𝑙ℎsubscript∇𝜃subscript𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎsubscript∇𝜃subscript^𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎsubscript∇𝜃subscript^𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥ℎG^{*}=[\nabla_{\theta}{l}_{max}(h),\nabla_{\theta}{l}_{1}(h),...,\nabla_{\theta}{l}_{N}(h),\nabla_{\theta}\bar{l}(h),\nabla_{\theta}f_{max}(h),\nabla_{\theta}\hat{l}_{max}(h),\nabla_{\theta}\hat{f}_{max}(h)]. We obtain the optimal d∗superscript𝑑d^{*} as follows,

d∗=arg⁡mind∈G∗​dT​∇θlm​a​x​(h),s.t.​dT​∇θl¯​(h)≤0,dT​∇θfm​a​x​(h)≤0​if​fm​a​x​(h)>ϵb,dT​∇θl^m​a​x​(h)≤0​if​l^m​a​x​(h)>ϵv​l,dT​∇θf^m​a​x​(h)≤0​if​f^m​a​x​(h)>ϵv​b,dT∇θli(h)≤0,∀i∈[N]andi≠argmax{lk(h)}k=1N.\begin{matrix}d^{*}=\arg\underset{d\in G^{*}}{\min}d^{T}\nabla_{\theta}{l}_{max}(h),\\ \text{s.t.}\,\,d^{T}\nabla_{\theta}\bar{l}(h)\leq 0,\,\,d^{T}\nabla_{\theta}{f}_{max}(h)\leq 0\,\,\text{if}\,\,{f}_{max}(h)>\epsilon_{b},\\ d^{T}\nabla_{\theta}\hat{l}_{max}(h)\leq 0\,\,\text{if}\,\,\hat{l}_{max}(h)>\epsilon_{vl},d^{T}\nabla_{\theta}\hat{f}_{max}(h)\leq 0\,\,\text{if}\,\,\hat{f}_{max}(h)>\epsilon_{vb},\\ d^{T}\nabla_{\theta}l_{i}(h)\leq 0,\forall i\in[N]\,\,and\,\,i\neq\arg\max\left\{l_{k}(h)\right\}_{k=1}^{N}.\end{matrix} (23)

The constraints are dynamically imposed, depending on whether the current hypotheses hℎh satisfies ϵbsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\epsilon_{b}-decision bias, ϵv​lsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙\epsilon_{vl}-egalitarian fairness on the accuracy and ϵv​bsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏\epsilon_{vb}-egalitarian fairness on the decision bias. The optimal gradient direction in Eq. 23 is optimized to minimize the empirical risk loss on the worst client without deteriorating the performance of other clients, resulting in a Pareto optimal hypothesis h∗superscriptℎh^{*}. The algorithm implementation in FL is described in the Appx. A.

5 Experiments

5.1 Settings

Datasets. ❶ We generate a synthetic dataset with a protected attribute: A∼B​e​r​(0.5)similar-to𝐴𝐵𝑒𝑟0.5A\sim Ber(0.5), two general attributes: X1∼𝒩​(0,1)similar-tosubscript𝑋1𝒩01X_{1}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1), X2∼𝒩​(𝟙​(a>0),2)similar-tosubscript𝑋2𝒩1𝑎02X_{2}\sim\mathcal{N}(\mathbbm{1}(a>0),2). The label is setting by Y∼B​e​r​(ul​𝟙​(x1+x2≤0)+uh​𝟙​(x1+x2>0))similar-to𝑌𝐵𝑒𝑟superscript𝑢𝑙1subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥20superscript𝑢ℎ1subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥20Y\sim Ber(u^{l}\mathbbm{1}(x_{1}+x_{2}\leq 0)+u^{h}\mathbbm{1}(x_{1}+x_{2}>0)), where {ul,uh}={0.3,0.6}superscript𝑢𝑙subscript𝑢ℎ0.30.6\left\{u^{l},u_{h}\right\}=\left\{0.3,0.6\right\} if a=0𝑎0a=0, otherwise,{ul,uh}={0.1,0.9}superscript𝑢𝑙superscript𝑢ℎ0.10.9\left\{u^{l},u^{h}\right\}=\left\{0.1,0.9\right\}. We split the dataset into two clients based on whether x1≤−0.3subscript𝑥10.3x_{1}\leq-0.3 to make the clients heterogeneous in distribution and size; ❷ Adult is a binary classification dataset with more than 400004000040000 adult records for predicting whether the annual income is greater than 50​K50𝐾50K. We split the dataset into two clients based on whether the individual’s education level is a Ph.D and select r​a​c​e𝑟𝑎𝑐𝑒race as a protected attribute; ❸ The eICU dataset includes data records about clinical information and hospital details of patients who are admitted to ICUs. The dataset has been processed following the steps outlined in Johnson et al. (2018). We filter out the hospitals with data points less than 150015001500, leaving 111111 hospitals in our experiments. Naturally, we treat each hospital as a client.

Baselines. ❶ FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017), ❷ FedAvg + FairBatch (Roh et al., 2021), ❸ FedAvG+FairReg, ❹ Ditto (Li et al., 2021), ❺ q-FFL (Li et al., 2019), ❻ FCFL (Cui et al., 2021), ❼ FedMDFG (Pan et al., 2023). All methods are tuned to their best performance.

Hyparameters We divide the communication rounds into three stages, each with 750750750, 750750750, and 500500500 rounds, respectively, to ensure that the global model is fully updated and converges in each stage. In the constraint budgets setting, we set the decision bias budget ϵbsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\epsilon_{b}, the egalitarian fairness budget on accuracy ϵv​lsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙\epsilon_{vl}, and the egalitarian fairness budget on decision bias ϵv​bsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏\epsilon_{vb} to half of the related-performance achieved by the original FedAvg. For example, as shown in Tab. 1, on the synthetic dataset experiments, the decision bias Avg. of FedAvg is 0.24800.24800.2480, so we set ϵb=0.1subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏0.1\epsilon_{b}=0.1. The accuracy Std. of FedAvg is 0.02830.02830.0283, so we set ϵv​l=0.01subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙0.01\epsilon_{vl}=0.01. The decision bias Std. of FedAvg is 0.08190.08190.0819, so we set ϵv​b=0.04subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏0.04\epsilon_{vb}=0.04. We use the same parameter setting strategy for other datasets. Since the constraints may conflict with each other, this setting allows us to better evaluate the superior performance of our proposed EFFL method and avoid making a constraint too tight, which may result in a solution that is only optimal on this constraint.

Evaluation Metrics. To evaluate the effectiveness and equality of the global model’s performance across all clients, we introduce three evaluation metrics under the accuracy and decision bias performance, respectively: ❶ Avg.: the average performance of the global model across all clients; ❷ Std.: the variation of the performance of the global model across clients. We utilize the TPSD defined in Eq. 4 as metric for decision bias. The results under APSD are reported in Appx. B.4.1.

More details about the experiments implementation and additional experiments are in the Appx. B.

5.2 Accuracy, Decision Bias and Egalitarian Fairness

We compare the global model performance of our proposed EFFL with other SOTA baselines on three datasets. In the EFFL problem setting, we introduce three types of constraints ϵbsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\epsilon_{b}, ϵv​lsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙\epsilon_{vl} and ϵv​bsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏\epsilon_{vb}, which are used to control the decision bias, the equality of accuracy performance distribution, and the equality of decision performance distribution, respectively. As shown in Tab. 1, our method achieves better satisfaction of the three constraints, with strict satisfaction under Synthetic and Adult datasets, and approximate satisfaction under eICU dataset. The current SOTA baselines are not able to guarantee all three constraints simultaneously. In terms of accuracy, the methods that do not consider decision bias (FedAvg, q-FFL, Ditto, and FedMDFG) have higher accuracy. However, as there is a trade-off between accuracy and decision bias, we compare our method with the baselines that also aim to reduce decision bias (FedAvg+FairBatch, FedAvg+FairReg, FCFL). Our method achieves the best constraint satisfaction with only 0.3% decrease in accuracy on the synthetic dataset, 0.7% decrease in accuracy on the adult dataset, and 0.2% decrease in accuracy on the eICU dataset.

Fig. 3 shows the convergent efﬁciency of EFFL within 200020002000 communication rounds on three datasets. The experiments are repeated 202020 times. We can observe that the optimization objective, accuracy of the global model converges as communication rounds progress, with the decision bias and the egalitarian fairness of accuracy and decision bias converging below the predefined budgets (bounded by the colored dashed lines in Fig. 3).

Figure 4 illustrates the distribution of model performance across various clients. We have conducted experiments on three distinct datasets. For a clearer visualization, we prioritize the display of baselines that also take into account decision bias (FedAvg+Fairbatch, FedAvg+FairReg, FCFL) on the eICU dataset, which encompasses 11 clients. The results clearly demonstrate that our proposed EFFL model ensures a more equitable performance distribution among clients, thereby indicating enhanced egalitarian fairness.

6 Conclusion

In this paper, we have investigated the egalitarian fairness issues in federated learning (FL), which have significant impacts on the sustainability of the FL system due to the Matthew Effect. We have analyzed the possible trade-offs for achieving egalitarian fairness and have formally defined Egalitarian Fairness Federated Learning (EFFL) as a multi-constrained multi-objectives optimization problem. Furthermore, we have designed an effective optimization path that decomposed the original problem into three sub-problems and proposed a three-stage algorithm to achieve Pareto optimal solutions under trade-offs. In the end, we have conducted a thorough empirical evaluation to demonstrate that our proposed method outperforms other state-of-the-art baselines in achieving a high-performance global model with enhanced egalitarian fairness among all clients.

Appendix A Algorithm Implement in Federated Learning

We give the implementation details of our proposed EFFL in Alg. 1:

Appendix B Experimental Details and Additional Experiments

B.1 Baseline Details

We adopt the following baselines, including:

(1) FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017): the original FL algorithm for distributed training of private data. It does not consider fairness for different demographic groups and different clients;

(2) FedAvg + FairBatch (Roh et al., 2021): each client adopts the state-of-the-art FairBatch in-processing debiasing strategy on its local training data and then aggregation uses FedAvg;

(3) FedAvG+FairReg: a local processing method by optimizing the linear scalarized objective with the fairness regularizations of all clients;

(4) Ditto (Li et al., 2021): an FL framework to achieve training fairness by allowing clients to run finetuning the received global model on the local data;

(5) q-FFL (Li et al., 2019): an FL framework to achieve fair loss among clients by weighing different local clients differently by taking the q-th power of the local empirical loss;

(6) FCFL (Cui et al., 2021): an FL framework to achieve algorithmic fairness across different local clients and consistency by minimizing the model loss of the worst-performed client;

(7) FedMDFG (Pan et al., 2023): a multiple gradient descent algorithm (MGDA)-based method by adding cosine similarity between the loss vectors among clients and the unit vector as a fairness objective.

B.2 Experimental Implementation Details

B.2.1 Normalization

We suggest normalizing the gradients before computing the optimal gradient descent direction d∗superscript𝑑d^{*} when there is a large disparity among the gradients, as in the eICU-related experiments where the number of clients is large. We experiment with three different methods of gradient normalization and find that the L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}-based method performs the best in practical. The gradient g=∇θl​(hθ)𝑔subscript∇𝜃𝑙subscriptℎ𝜃g=\nabla_{\theta}l(h_{\theta}) can be normalized by the following three methods:

L2−based:𝐠=𝐠/∑i=1|g|gi2.:subscriptL2based𝐠𝐠superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖2\mathrm{L_{2}-based}:\mathbf{g}=\mathbf{g}/\sqrt{{\textstyle\sum_{i=1}^{\left|g\right|}g_{i}^{2}}}. (28)
Loss−based:𝐠=𝐠/l​(hθ).:Lossbased𝐠𝐠𝑙subscriptℎ𝜃\mathrm{Loss-based}:\mathbf{g}=\mathbf{g}/l(h_{\theta}). (29)
L2+Loss−based:𝐠=𝐠/(∑i=1|g|gi2×l​(hθ)).:subscriptL2Lossbased𝐠𝐠superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖2𝑙subscriptℎ𝜃\mathrm{L_{2}+Loss-based}:\mathbf{g}=\mathbf{g}/\left(\sqrt{{\textstyle\sum_{i=1}^{\left|g\right|}g_{i}^{2}}}\times l(h_{\theta})\right). (30)

B.3 Time Complexity Analysis

Ignoring the communication time between clients and server, in a scenario with N𝑁N clients, the time consumption involved in solving EFFL given by Alg. 1 mainly comes from: (1) the gradient computation on local clients, which is O​(|𝒟k|​d)𝑂subscript𝒟𝑘𝑑O(\left|\mathcal{D}_{k}\right|d) for k𝑘k-th client, where |𝒟k|subscript𝒟𝑘\left|\mathcal{D}_{k}\right| is the size of the dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} owned by the k𝑘k-th client and d𝑑d is the data feature dimension; (2) the d∗superscript𝑑d^{*} solving: for a linear programming problem, minx∈ℝn​AT​x,s.t.​C​x=b,x≥0formulae-sequence𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛superscript𝐴𝑇𝑥s.t.𝐶𝑥𝑏𝑥0\underset{x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}}{\min}A^{T}x,\text{s.t.}\,\,Cx=b,x\geq 0 with n𝑛n variables and Ω​(n)Ω𝑛\Omega(n) constraints, it can be solved in polynomial time of O~∗​(nω)superscript~𝑂superscript𝑛𝜔\widetilde{O}^{*}\left(n^{\omega}\right) (Alman & Williams, 2021), where ω𝜔\omega is the exponent of matrix multiplication. The current best known upper bound is ω<2.3728596𝜔2.3728596\omega<2.3728596 (Cohen et al., 2021), which implies a time complexity not exceeding O~∗​(n2.38)superscript~𝑂superscript𝑛2.38\widetilde{O}^{*}\left(n^{2.38}\right). Therefore, in our proposed three-stage gradient descent direction d∗superscript𝑑d^{*} solving, the time consumption does not exceed O~∗​(22.38)+O~∗​(42.38)+O~∗​((N+4)2.38)superscript~𝑂superscript22.38superscript~𝑂superscript42.38superscript~𝑂superscript𝑁42.38\widetilde{O}^{*}\left(2^{2.38}\right)+\widetilde{O}^{*}\left(4^{2.38}\right)+\widetilde{O}^{*}\left((N+4)^{2.38}\right). Based on the above analysis, the time consumption in Stage 111 and Stage 222 is mainly affected by the gradient computation on local clients and with only a constant computation time spent on d∗superscript𝑑d^{*}. In Stage 333, compared to Stage 111 and Stage 222, the computation time spent on d∗superscript𝑑d^{*} increases, depending on the number of clients, but overall, it is still bounded by polynomial time complexity.

B.4 Additional Experiments

In this section, we provide additional experiments, including the algorithm performance comparison on another decision bias metric, APSD, the effect of the constraint budgets and the robustness of EFFL.

B.4.1 Accuracy, Group Fairness and Egalitarian Fairness (APSD)

In this experiment, we adopt APSD in Eq. 3 as decision bias metric and compare the global model performance of our proposed EFFL with other SOTA baselines on three datasets. As shown in Tab. 2, our method achieves best satisfaction of the three constraints, while current SOTA baselines are not able to guarantee all three constraints simultaneously. As there is a trade-off between accuracy and decision bias, we evaluate the accuracy performance by comparing with the baselines that satisfy the ϵb−limit-fromsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\epsilon_{b}-decision bias constraint. Our proposed EFFL achieves the best constraints satisfaction with only 0.3% decrease in accuracy under synthetic and adult datasets, and 0.2% decrease in accuracy under eICU datasets.

B.4.2 Efficiency of Constraint Budgets

In EFFL, we introduce three constraint budgets, ϵbsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\epsilon_{b}, ϵv​lsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙\epsilon_{vl} and ϵv​bsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏\epsilon_{vb}, to control the decision bias performance of the global model on the clients, the egalitarian fairness of the accuracy and decision bias performance distribution among the clients, repectively. To explore the effect of different budgets settings on EFFL, we use the Adult dataset as an example and set the values of ϵbsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\epsilon_{b}, ϵv​lsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙\epsilon_{vl} and ϵv​bsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏\epsilon_{vb} to [0.001,0.01,0.02,0.05,0.1]0.0010.010.020.050.1\left[0.001,0.01,0.02,0.05,0.1\right] respectively.

The result in Fig. 5 shows that: (1) ϵbsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\epsilon_{b} has the ability to control the decision bias of the global model, and the smaller the ϵbsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\epsilon_{b}, the lower the decision bias of the global model; (2) ϵv​lsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙\epsilon_{vl} and ϵv​bsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏\epsilon_{vb} have the ability to control the equality of the performance of the global model on the clients, specifically, the smaller the ϵv​lsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑙\epsilon_{vl}, the smaller the standard deviation of accuracy among the clients; the smaller the ϵv​bsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑣𝑏\epsilon_{vb}, the smaller the standard deviation of decision bias among the clients.

B.4.3 Robustness under Attack

We conduct robustness validation experiments on the eICU dataset and randomly select 444 clients to be malicious. The malicious clients adopt the following attacks to dominate or disrupt the FL process: (1) Enlarge: the malicious clients enlarge the local gradients or local model parameters sent to the server to enhance their influence in the training process. In our experiments, we set the enlarging factor to 101010; (2) Random: the malicious clients send randomly generated local gradients or model parameters to the server to disrupt the training process; (3) Zero: The malicious clients send zero local gradients or zero model parameters to the server to disrupt the training process. Tab. 3 shows the testing performance of the SOTA baselines and our EFFL under attacks. The performance metrics include the mean and standard deviation of accuracy and decision bias of the global model on all clients. The results demonstrate that our EFFL is robust and the performance of the global model does not degrade due to the presence of malicious clients, while other baselines suffer from different degrees of decline in testing performance. The three-stage algorithm to solve EFFL provides equal gradient descent directions that ensure that even if malicious clients are attempting to dominate the model training, EFFL can still protect the performance of the honest clients and prevent them from being discriminated, and ensures that the model’s performance is not compromised under attack.
